DsQg2FI2mOGQORy0o_fHpg.text: Greatest cheese shop ever! All right, maybe I'm exaggerating but just a bit. This shop stores a lot of varieties of mainly French but also English and Italian cheese. The staff is very helpful and they are happy to give you a taste before you buy. The "morbier" I bought there was the best ever and not even that expensive. On top of the cheese, you can also find great charcuterie, fresh fruits, homemade cakes or fresh eggs. Love it!!!

k3KjHUtnoDXdGG-Q2F2haQ.text: I would almost move to Marylebone just to be near La Fromagerie.  If you love good food, this is your heaven.  From top-quality/specialty breads, oils, butters, cakes, chocolate, wine, jams and vinegars to the tiny "tasting cafe" and the star of the show, a temperature controlled, beautiful cheese room, you can't help but to be inspired - if not to buy, then to sample.  Or to eat.  Two big wooden communal tables comprise the "cafe" where one can feast on meals made with the shop's goodies for breakfast, lunch, afternoon tea or a very early supper.  They don't take reservations so be prepared to wait (maybe in the cheese room?).La Fromagerie also holds monthly "tutored" tasting events - joy.

dfLFJE_WHkdtaIxIMfhqHg.text: Great shop with a bit of a "hidden gem" vibe. More cheeses than I have ever seen in my life, plus assorted other produce and gourmet foods. The restaurant is good, too. A little pricey, and the queues can be annoying, but definitely worth a visit.

t4oqMQGWjSa-QBF19uFiOA.text: Le Fromagerie was always one of our favourite Artisan type places to have a good breakfast and soak up the rustic atmosphere of the shop floor with their great selection of cheeses and top class Deli essentials. For breakfast I normally go for the Boiled Egg and soldiers-scrumptious! Very disappointed however the last time I went there as it was very very busy and we missed the breakfast slot. That said we queued and opted for the lunch menu instead. Not really fancying the heavy food choices we both opted for one of their tarts. Very very tasty but the portion size was very measley especially at £8 a serving. I would go back from my boiled eggs and soldiers but not for the lunch as I think it's a bit pricey for what it is. That's a bit of a shame so maybe brush up on your portion sizes please!

btUGCrCRGgtZEec-FtNakw.text: Just slide that glass door and let me in with the cheese! Quite happy to pass the rest of my days inside that room. Wel, maybe I'll stock up on some of the violet lollies, some charcuterie, bread and olive oil and then go to my cheese room....

oYccrSzPU5VcIbCz-GJu2Q.text: What a nice little cheese shop set in quaint Marylebone High St. I went in one day, and was warmly greeted by an nice middle-aged man, who I assume was the manager. I told him what kind of cheese I was looking for and he was so kind to have me sample a variety of cheeses until I found what I wanted. And then he gave me free bread to go with it! The cheese itself was lovely and I will definitely be coming back for more.

mirAc4bJ4GqhsWAaME2gKg.text: Fantastic (if very smelly) cheese room, sealed room, they only allow a certain amount of people in at a time and it can get very busy, particularly when the Farmers market is on. The staff are all very knowledgeable and helpful, once you can get their attention. I often take their recommendations and have never been disappointed. Other produce available, crackers, chutneys, jams, fruit, breads, but it's all about the cheese really. Love it.

KxNFg_PhsupCHCD2WIxtNQ.text: Stay away from this place if you like a nice friendly place to have your food. The food was good but the manager treated the people at the table next to me appallingly. I don't know what the conflict was about, but what happened to the idea that the customer is always right? Even challenging customers need to be dealt with professionally to avoid killing the atmosphere for every one else. The cafe is very nice but the management was very poor on my visit.

0qWZiwmDvmz2XLqqoBBg_A.text: This tastin cafe at the back of a Mrylebone Gourmet cheese shop is very attractively skylit.Its does packed over the weekends when local foodies and people from outside the area cram in here and congregate at the communal table. Many like to wait for a table but sometimes they jus have to share. The cheese plate is the centre piece of this establishment. All of the cheeses have detailed descriptions should you want to buy any and take them home.Other than that there were various pies,charcuterie and fish dishes on the menu.The staff were knowledgeable and helpful.

u1BkfOaG3onL_EJlXGHeOw.text: The cheese and other food in this place is great and the staff is for the most part very friendly and helpful. The owner, however, is a rude elderly man who can barely even bring himself to scowl at his customers. I used to go quite often but can't stand to be ignored and barked at by this man any more. Sometimes I walk by and see if he's in there; if not I'll go in but otherwise I just keep walking. He should stay in the back and let his far more competent staff deal with the customers. I should note that this review is of the Highbury branch of the shop.

QBpEmW2qwk9yoGzH59j-Xg.text: I had La Fromagerie on my list of places to try for a long time, mainly because i had heard great things about the place and because I am big on cheese. It was better than I thought. Of course the place is about cheese and the section of the shop dedicated to cheese is quite spectacular and worth the visit, but La Fromagerie more than that. The decor is charming, quite busy and full of stuff but looking good, the place has a sense of authenticity and feels quite unique, and the products (mainly food delicatessen, both salty and sweet) look and taste good. La Fromagerie is also a great place for a simple lunch with friends or family. We had a wonderful Italian waitress who was extremely friendly and took great care of our table and 2 little girls in particular. I had the rabbit stwe which was excellent (the most expensive plate on the menu at £13) and a glass of very good Italian Barolo which was recommended. Note that the service was great (in our case) while this is one of the few places in London where you don't get the optional 12% service charge included so service charge is really up to you. Any course on the menu is available for take-away , something that must be pretty popular with the locals We will be back during another visit of the charming and central Maryleborne Village

f5pmaeNIS_kBkHLvKGeZJw.text: two points deducted for occassional snooty service. the other day i was in there and i was almost spoken down to for asking for a certain cheese that apparently wasnt in season (he later admitted he was confused and he'd got it wrong) but it wound me up no end. that said the most impressive thing about this place is the cheese on offer and the tastings they can arrange for you. the baked goods are overpriced and some of the staff are far too junior to justify the attitude and prices this place sets for itself. but if youre looking for faults it's a sign that it's a decent place to start with. but i would say it's got worse rather than better over the last 4 years or so.

6W7jwRtr9IdS84k45Q4Efw.text: There is a cheese room like you cannot believe. It is a refrigerated room stack from floor to ceiling with pretty much every cheese you can imagine. The smell is quite incredible and the staff do know their stuff. You can try anything you like before buying. Genius. This is a real hidden gem in London - do not miss it. There is also a cosy little cafe which does great coffee and cake.

hL-DocbyriqRBwlDAWhg8A.text: I was really really really hoping this was going to be a 5 star place.  I didn't even have these expectations because of Yelp--I didn't read about it before going.  My friend took me there and I immediately fell in love with the ambiance.  Cheese and goodies shop, beautiful merchandising, and a lovely community table for sharing cheese, salads, meat plates and yummy-looking desserts.  The benches have a slot for storing your bag--perfect!  The cheese we had was yummy.  The salads weren't as great as I had hoped, nor was the quiche.  Some of the salads were drowned in oil and I just had such high hopes that were a bit dashed when I put the food in my mouth.The brownies did smell good and the merengue and Valrhona chocolate and hazelnut torte was very impressive looking.  Definitely a place to put on the list, but not an OMG I will die if I don't get back there ASAP place.  For innovative salads and desserts, Ottolenghi still is my go-to.

cTuU1u7TQuHE5Csg6bn0wA.text: I rarely get up to Marylebone but when I do I always seem to end up at La Fromagerie. What a charming little place, like a restaurant with a French accent if you know what I mean. La Fromagerie, as the name promises, is predominantly a cheese shop with an amazing cheese room, which you can also check out online (Online cheese room). I could not believe my eyes  they even have cheese from Austria! (they do deserve credit for this as you cannot say that Austria is exactly famous for its cheese) In the middle of all these great food stuff (olive oil to die for, delicious looking bread, chocolates etc..) there is a small attractive cafe/restaurant area with rustic wood tables and chairs. The menu is small but hits the spot and all the ingredients are top class. We had the vegetarian Antipasti Plate (8.95) with lovely humus and smoked aubergine puree which I have hardly eaten better. It came with sun dried tomatoes, artichokes, olives and tasty goat's cheese garnished with fresh leaves and herbs. We also shared the absolutely delicious House Dry Cured Beef Fillet (14.50), carpaccio with pecorino cheese, salad leaves/rocket and truffle oil. Very very nice indeed. please see alsohungryinlondon.com/2010/…  We were not quite sated yet and tried one of their cheeses which we had bought before in their cheese room. When we asked for knife and bread, they gave us the bread for free. How rare is this? We decided on a French goat's cheese called Banon which came wrapped in wine leaves and was perfectly ripe and melting and delightful. We were not planning on eating the whole thing actually but there was no holding us back La Fromagerie offers a good, fair-priced wine list. When we couldn't decide which wine to take, the waitress let us try different ones until we made up our mind. The service yes  they were lovely and attentive and helpful and the service charge was not included. That's when you like giving! So I hope I have convinced you that this is the perfect place for a unpretentious, relaxed and satisfactory meal. On the downside  I might just never try anything else in Marylebone

1TS7pwM0mgIW44J3CPeCXA.text: Stop and smell the cheese!   If you're anywhere within a 1km radius you'll probably be able to follow your nose Toucan Sam style straight into this joint -- but considering Toucan Sam is about as easy to come by in London as good Mexican food, I'll just leave it at stop and smell the cheese.This is probably my favourite place in London to pop by for a quick cheese plate and crisp bottle of white. While last time I sampled a few other menu items, nothing blew me away nearly as much as the cheese.  (So it's not just a creative name...)Walking through a veritable market of colours where fresh veggies and chocolates fill barrels and olive oils and peppers line the walls, you'll find a quaint little seating area in the back and it's almost like you're seated at a secret chef's table. Sit there long enough and you'll be treated to samples from the various deliciousness found around the shop! Word to the wise: probably not the best place for the faint of smelly-tolerance.  You can literally smell the dank moist of cheese sweat. (Which might also double as the most disgusting line ever written on Yelp.) Cheers!

49HmADTQ_hwdOaWBKveGWQ.text: Ewhhh, it smells like stinky cheese in here!Oh wait, it's a cheese shop. Okay, moving on. This place is awesome once your nasal passages adjust to the stank whiff you get once you enter it. There are tons of cute little foodie things to pick up and fondle, along with edibles like multicolored carrots, veggies and caramel.There is a small sitting area with a nice and big communal table made of strong thick wood. It isn't exactly level so mind your wine glass as you might have a case of spillage if you aren't careful.We tried the cheese plate and of course the Charcutterie creation, along with a bottle of the house white. It is really a tasty, nicely priced bottle too and paired well with our nibblies and the soup of the day that my friend got.This just seems like a great place to come with a friend for some gossiping and catching up or on a date... but only the kind of date where you are comfortable with the surrounds of stink, tasty stink at that :)

1AIcmuZzMFszcg_LdjjgyA.text: La Fromagerie is an incredible place to go for cheese-you will always find something delicious, unique, and at just the right ripeness. Their staff is very knowledgeable and able to help you find just the right thing.I also love their cafe. They have a simple menu, with a daily cheese board, a selection of salads, a few warm dishes, desserts, and a small selection of beer and wine.Patricia, the owner, is incredibly passionate, and has created a business that really shows her appreciation for all foods artisinal and traditional.

8gKqOHhBnKTX7Xcd3e4LHA.text: Cheesee. Magnificent place, cannot describe it. Two thumbs up!

6ZUpsypV4n7sORQXAsji5A.text: La Fromagerie at Marylebone is a little heaven for cheese lovers.All the other products and snack are great, but this is their strong point.Delicious and special! the staff is knowledgeable and friendly, and its a great place to visit.

bn6pzUfE0zhDI50xBE644g.text: Oooh what a great little place! I've never spent a huge amount of time in this part of town. Which I've now realised is stupid. Really stupid. So now I'm going to come to Marylebone at the weekends (not on a Sunday, all of the shops are shut), and then I'll spend all of my money and be very poor. I'll probably spend most of my money in La Fromagerie. The perfect place for lunch and gossip. And then I'll buy tasty cheesy treats and yummy salad things. All sorts of nice things for my tea. It's ace in here. I'd like to live here and just eat cheese.

EATQJTpUJDooq6e_7KXTDw.text: What a charming place. it is a cheese haven with it;s own chilled cheese room. Also loved it that the back room has so much light because of the sunroof. very different and a must visit if you are planning a wine and cheese party. The alpine cheese plate selection was very good.

2KTg0OWLfZPPL8R3xwmNXA.text: Breakfast, yesterday. Bacon sandwich and the spring cheese board are a delicious, perfect way to start a busy day. The unexpected wow was the home made ketchup! Delicious!!

CAfGuhnyTtX8xLpRSsPHpA.text: If mice died and went to heaven, this is probably what the place would look like...A gorgeous shop/cafe/restaurant built around the 'cheese room'.The restaurant is tiny, but the cheese menu is unbelievably fabulous.Not cheap, but then this is about love. Love of cheese.They have other good stuff to sell and on the menu, and the wine list is pretty good. Cakes look very very tempting (but I stuck to cheese).Absolutely worth a visit if you are near Marylebone Street

zZ2hpdyfVW5BnQDeJr15ug.text: This is proper quality dairy products cheese like you could never dream of, even in your wildest dreams. So many of them, so little time!There are so many sorts of them that you can barely choose from and they all look amazingly appetizing.The whole place is actually brilliant as they also sell cured meat and a beautiful selection of cakes and sweet.They have a small area where you can sit at the back of the shop and enjoy some delicacies.Really a wonderful place to discover and enjoy

r0e5G_hDO5SvFtvOWt5_Ew.text: I wanted to go to this place ages ago and did so the other day(02/01/08)This place is lovely. There is a main long table in which you will be seated next to other people and even might chat with them if you feel friendly... there are also some tables for two. We had 3 dishes:1. chorizo soup2. leek pie3. salad with parma ham,butternut squash, nuts, lettuce and other stuff...we also had a small cheese plate at the end.The food was great- small portions but very tasty and fresh.

tKxR4L3NoFejVPcAlXe4IA.text: Whenever i'm around this way I pop in to La Fromagerie to explore the dozens of cheeses i've never tried before. It isn't cheap in here, but a for a cheese shop of this calibre you wouldn't expect it to be. The walk in humidor is a brilliant way to display their range, and the cheesemongers themselves knowledgable and friendly. I'm sure i'll be back in there soon.

6dYeLlC55MLcayL55ETtpw.text: I love Marylebone! Its always busy and has a nice village feeling to it. And discovering La Fromagerie has been great. Breakfast there is amazing and you always bump into such interesting people - the communal tables make it so easy to meet and chat.The cheeseroom is really special, too. The only downside for me, a foodie, but not "smelly cheese" lover is the smell of cheese!A very cool place though

vo-SC-dx3qHQ_FettPXfJw.text: The cheese room here is amazing. Most worth a try- Vacherin Mont D'Or when in season, and the black truffle Brie. If you fancy a light snack whilst shopping in Marylebone, the cafe at the back of La Fromagerie is nice- the cheese tasting plate is always good, and they do a delightful violet prosecco- not sure it quite goes with the cheese, but yummy all the same. Latte's also nice here, but again not complementary to the star of the show, the cheeses...

xmaHx43OGOEOckgGCbIATw.text: I LOVE LA FROMAGERIE. This is the ultimate mix of olt-timey mercantile meets foodie dream shop. Nestled in a chic shopping hood, this great lunch spot is totally a must hit while in london. I ducked in with my london beau for a bite, a coffee and a rechage. Our food was amazing, i found the prices fair, and the ambiance unparalleled by many ofther places. I love having a london crush...they know all the hotspots. You should check out this place if you are into cute, great, chic and fun---oh and cheese.

WoZ7vICYivCIGtngo_58Sw.text: I'd come here just to hang out in the cheese room with the charming staff who are knowledgeable and helpful and very generous with samples. Don't come here without some leeway for spending though - you'll always spend more on cheese than you expect!

gCX12E27sriqukg3lIjCUw.text: Mmmm... Amazing little cheese shop/veggie shop/restaurant in the heart of Marylebone.  Lines can be long but the food is fantastic, fresh and organic.  No better place to have a nice long lunch in Marylebone.

vg-aTY_zIiDCCPxGQTvN6A.text: One of my favorite weekend haunts. And I am not alone in that. Why can't everything in the world be as perfect as this little place? Yes, its a cheese room with a cafe bit. The magic though is that there is so much love for what is being done in this place. And they do it soooo well! Whenever I go I have a cheese plate and I always try something new, I love the blurbs on the menu about where the cheeses have originated. Its all good. I often order two dishes and eat them both. One criticism. They can't really make coffee - so leave that for some where else.

qajjSkjII9Bi_49Hf870KA.text: MY IDEAL shop!!! we were in London for a wedding staying nearby at Durrants hotel...the bride (a designer) put together a wonderful list of where to eat and where to vist/shop etc. I was happy here the moment I stepped through the door! lovely fresh vegetables beautifully displayed greet you upon entry and the back room with long rustic wooden table, beckons. We ditched the hotel breakfast (OK, but nothing great) to eat here for breakfast instead.  I was served: a huge free range brown egg, nested in a lovely earthenware cup w. little cups of salt and ground pepper, GREAT toasted whole grain bread all on an earthenware plate. I ordered a cappuccino the entire thing was absolutely yummy and aesthetically pleasing. I could not keep my eyes off the shelves of lovely unique Les Grimauds ceramics from France (I purchased a big box of these) and the cheese room was filled with delights! I also discovered the delicious little artisanal french yogurts that I got completely hooked on!  O! if only there were a store such as this in either Brooklyn or St Louis where I live.  SAD ole me!The help is really great here and honestly I could eat here everyday. The other breakfast offerings I saw made my mouth drop open.  Its all great here!

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. husbands salmon themed breakfast
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. more Les Grimauds: cheese board in ceramic
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. cute little radishes greet you

U9BPnKpWq9ccQUUOZ96z_A.text: I'm beginning to feel like Yelp is the new AYSO where everyone gets a trophy/five stars for having a quirky little name and being in a cute area. It's not to say we didn't have an ok meal. The butternut squash I had for lunch was DELICIOUS, and free of cream which is increasingly rare. Very rich, nice toasted pumpkin seeds, and just the right amount of spice.  My bf's roast beef was decidedly less appealing- flavorless, rather grey, and reminiscent of an Arby's castaway (albeit much more expensive). Perhaps we caught them on a bad day/ordered the wrong thing. The place was packed and the market definitely looked enticing, so I'd be willing to give it one more shot (but not five stars...yet).

rgLybPGY1hByPVFxAwktfA.text: This is a bit of a dream shop. The kind of place I would love to own. The informal tables give an intimate feel and the menu is fantastic, such a wonderful choice and generous portions. The cheese boards are incredible and offer great selections which change all the time. Perfect to share. I've always been with friends, but this would be a great place to take a date.

OAE6EnCgOmfwCSQPpgv_4g.text: Cheese lovers will be more than amazed when they discover La Fromagerie  a restaurant and a shop combined in one with staff that are incredibly knowledgeable about both the cheese and the wine that they offer. The temperature-controlled cheese room is situated in the front of the shop and that is where where all the different types of cheese 'rest'.

fUqjW5_37iELzgd0e8pkiQ.text: Do you like delicious cheese paired expertly with a bottle of wine?COOL, well you can get that here, if you are prepared to wait five thousand years. We ordered a large cheese plate, a bottle of wine and apparently also 40 minutes of admiring the atmosphere, which was filled with patrons asking when their own cheese plate and bottle of wine would be available. It was like a cruel cruel hazing cycle where we watched with our own eyes as people who had ordered before us endured a lengthy interval before their food came. Yet, we still hoped that our own experience would be different and remained cruelly silent when new people were seated. "No!" we should have shouted, "Leave this place now, while you still can! Before you are trapped by the promise of cheeeeese."There was allegedly only one cheese preparer in the kitchen working on all these complex creations. I am no expert cheesemonger, but I imagine the slicing and plating of dairy products does not in itself require many minutes of contemplation. Mysteries!

S1t1_Iw7Srj6Va92petm3w.text: Service is 5 star. As far as the food it's I went for blu cheese, bre and some other one that I didn't agree with but the quality of product is  love the atmosphere great service and food and I am a sucker for good cheese!

AV9dJjAKwPTXiI63XffmTg.text: As a fan of the other La Fromagerie, I decided to make a quick stop in at this one since I was in the area. It's definitely larger than its sister. More seating room, more food stuff for sale, and a bigger closed off cheese room. However, the size of the cheese room seemed to make it less impressive to me, as a very tiny room filled to the brim with a massive selection of cheeses just seemed to be an amazing thing.Not that it would stop me from coming here or shopping here. However, since the other La Fromagerie is closer to home, it's more likely to be where I stop for cheese. Especially if they also have that truffle stuffed brie that I was drooling over at this one.

-1Gd_64JcuWNh7S4FcumtA.text: Lovely specialist cheese shop with a deli shop and cafe attached. I'm sure you can get ANY type of cheese here, there are so many to choose from! They have the cheese kept in a large refridgerated room accessed through a sliding door.Staff knowledgeable about their cheese too.The cafe is cute, nice snacky food, cheese (of course!) wine, coffee and soft drinks also sold.If you are in the area, fancy some nice cheese or are just feeling a bit cheesy I recommend checking it out!

bdB3Sl3c_vG7ivKIclo28w.text: Very cute little place, close by to the Marylebone market (a must go btw!). And this is great because it's allows me to combine both and have the perfect Sunday = market shopping in the morning, wonderful lunch at the market and cooking/dinner with friends in the evening!La Fromagerie is a combination of a cheese shop, an Italian grocery, a wine shop and a delicious foodie restaurant. I'm not a huge fan of the grocery part as prices are really expensive (which is costing them 1 star). But it adds to the decor, and makes the whole place very special!The little/tiny restaurant is tucked in a the back, under a nice roof window that brings a lot of light. There's one big main table in the middle and then 2-seat tables on the sides and a stool-bar type table running along the back wall. And a few tables where the wine is stored in a little other room. And it's not really rooms per say, everything is open. It's more like a wonderful labyrinth, with loads of temptations all over the place :DThe menu is simple, and very yummy. Fresh stuff all the time. This Sunday we had the rabbit ravioli with sage butter and a little Parmesan. So delicious. Unbelievable. With a full body red wine. And then I took the chocolate & mascarpone cream cake. It was a food orgasm :)You also have choices of platters (cheese, meat, fish) to share, which is nice when with friends. Most of the food is on display here and there, so it's hard to resist! Specially the desserts.Just go, enter and enjoy. I bet you stay to eat!And staff is friendly, and chillaxed. What more do you want on a WE?

HMCsde7hS4KHCePVoY5nhA.text: I love coming here and entering the shrine of cheese, almost spiritual. Lots of other tasty goodies. Glad I do not live too close or I would end up spending all my money here.

j1IY8OWj0vQsTtR3W1r47Q.text: I have been here so many times. The service is laughably bad. You can fall asleep and not be disturbed. The staff either purposely ignore you or look at you with a zombie stare. The food, wine and cheese are excellent although there are buzzing flies to keep you company. The seating is a la mode school refectory type benches and inexorably uncomfortable unless you are under 30 which I am not. The Aubaine across the street has an excellent view of the Fromagerie and has good food, service and seats. This would be the only way to enjoy this rather quirky rude institution.

RAlc_Zj0cpCE4YWtkRGgqA.text: I love La Fromagerie! I first went here with my friend who needed to buy a selection of cheeses for a dinner party event and was dragged into the 'famous' large cheese refrigerator. The shop sells a selection of high quality ingredients, free produced and baked goods. Warning: the groceries here are very expensive. My friend brought three small cheeses for £40.In the heart of the shop, there is a small cafe but it looks more like a communal kitchen/dinning room.A few months later I decided to try out the tasting cafe inside the shop on my second visit. We arrived very late into the afternoon and was told the kitchen was closed and that we could only order the drinks and their selection of cakes and cheeses, proceeding with the order despite the restricted menu anyways! Having settled down on the communal benches and tables.I opted for the cheesecake (£4) and elderflower cordial (£1.50). The drink was massive, you could fill up two glasses shared between two. Tasty and dear might I say better than the homemade cordial I make myself!Cheesecake was nice, light and cheesy. New York styled baked cheesecake type with sour cream at the top. My friends opted for the lovely carrot cake which was MASSIVE and coffee.  We shared the cheese board (£8) which was amazing. We got the larger size plate of british cheese and shared between three people. It did not seem like a lot but the cheese was very filling.You could eat one large cheeseboard by yourself if you are a massive cheese lover.My university campus is nearby so whenever  I need a self indulgence in food, I know I will definitely be here again.

2WKDdlVZdvn0mpmJWPXO0w.text: Cheese and Charcuterie sitting on the shelf; s-m-e-l-l-i-n-g, buy away Cheese; eat away CharcuterieCome back to La Fromagerie!

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom

21M-Vxwz6kutsaZfBlqN2Q.text: I recently visited this cheese shop and was drawn in by the beautiful display and look of the shop. They had an amazing selection of cheese and the sales people were very helpful and helped me decide which cheese to go for. I bought 2 really lovely cheeses that I never had before and I'm very pleased with my choice. The only thing I would say is that it's a little pricey but makes for a nice shopping experience.

v2k2EgNJhd2UcliqP6BeKQ.text: This is posh foodie heaven. Everything here is absolutely delectable, enticingly displayed and more often than not, sourced abroad especially from France and Italy. Unsurprisingly, given its name, cheese is the big deal here and there is a large tasting room, temperature controlled and pungent to put it politely. However, there are also myriad other options including the best clementines I have ever eaten, chocolates and special blends of tea and coffee.There is also a cafe which serves possibly the best brownies in London alongside other tasty treats. It's not cheap but it is good quality, although I was surprised when the creme fraiche that I was offered with my brownie (excellent for cutting through the richness of the chocolate) was charged as extra on the bill. Still, if you can afford it, this is a great shop for all the special things in life, and if you can't, this is still a lovely place to pick up a tiny morsel of cheese or very occasional jar of something as a gourmet treat.

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom

GmCq62DllDPND09kuCOEZw.text: Gorgeous cheese shop, though my biggest complaint is that the cheese name, region and type of milk are not clearly written down. These are things I need to know!When entering the cheese room one must go through sliding glass doors which lead to a humidity controlled room. The walls are lined with wooden aging racks and the cheeses are huddled in groups (by type) for display. Samples are available but I'm not sure that they are common. The sales person who was helping us seemed a bit taken aback when we asked for a sample of a very expensive cheese. The food is not as good as I hoped. I had the roast beef with beets and horseradish. BF had nettle soup which was stunningly smooth and creamy.A great book to read before or after this shop is "The Cheese Room" by Patricia Michelson. She is the owner and her book is absolutely wonderful.

bzxH__fMa1rMEdP3GyRnew.text: This really is a must-see (or should that be 'must-smell'?) for cheese lovers in London. A large shop-front more or less entirely devoted to the art of fromage, you'll be sure to find something you love here, as well as something new to try. The chilled cheese room is a real treat, and it's staffed by helpful people who really know their cheese. Back in the main part of the shop, you'll find everything you need to accompany your cheese from fresh veg to chutneys, interesting crackers and artisan bread. There's also a dining area where cheese tasting courses are regularly held. This is one of two branches of La Fromagerie, as there is a much more compact outpost in Highbury. For those not in the immediate vicinity, the website is well worth a look too: not only does it have some very evocative cow-bells to accompany your online shopping - it has a 'virtual cheeseroom', too. Genius.

J2Lw8U-3wbOXXCo-yP3GpQ.text: lovely little gourmet shop - from a temperature controlled cheese room to the yummiest of produce and gourmet cupboard products.  lunch was a clean, yet filling, salad of squash, green beans, lettuce, topped with some cheese.  i think the portions are good for a girl...i think my husband would have considered it an appetizer salad.the cheese is so reasonably priced for as vast of a selection and professionally prepared room.  it's even cheaper than whole-paycheck...hey, i'll pay for good grub any day but a good price to boot?  that's definitely worth a visit and a little party favor to take home.

f2FpOljU1nc_czHupgt-Ww.text: Favorite hot spot in this neighborhood... All the samples you could wish for and every cheese you could want! Been here today will make 3 times in 2 weeks.... Truffle Brie how I love thee

QjBnTquBFWN7DrTocsEBBA.text: Sublime. I went to buy cheese for a dinner with friends, the gentlemen had worked there for 9 years, was more than happy to recommend four cheeses, the order of them, the why of it and the nuances of each. He suggested wines as well. I asked if he loved his work and he said that he could not imagine anything better. Go to the shop and you shall see why.I liked it so much, I stayed for a quick lunch in the restaurant. Lovely.

0WOxkX7vjzbCMvIRUCp3TQ.text: A wonderful spot for an afternoon snack. A group of us shared the British and Irish Cheese Board and a charcuterie plate. The cheeses were spectacular. I highly suggest having their recommended drink pairings. They recommended the Commonside Pale Ale to go with the cheeses we selected. I probably wouldn't drink this beer regularly but it was fantastic when paired with the cheese. The atmosphere is casual and unpretentious. Wish there was a place like this in my hometown.

2z66Wkw8ciRSW6cO7yWPVA.text: Do you love cheese? Are you comfortable with spending a bit more to have the ultimate cheese experience? If yes, you will love this place.  It features a cheese locker.  Not only can you have a cheese emersion, the helpful staff will let you sample cheeses until you find the one right for you.  In front, Fromagerie also has a charming restaurant area.  The food, while solid, features snacks.  We love to go and grab wine on a Friday evening.  It tends to be decently slow (which is appreciated) and it is fun to drink in a relaxed environment with cheese and candle light.

40ta3VlZU9t9tcqUKd1TWA.text: Everyone, without exception, should come here to wander around and gawk at the products, the produce and prices.A wonderful grocer that proudly displays beautiful home grown veg that displays not a wrinkle, a crack, a wart or a disfigurement of any kind. The cakes look as if they have been prepared for an immanent photo shoot, and the prices clearly mark the items as luxury products - but with luxury comes desirability, and I want them, i want them all.There is a cheese shop on the front right corner of the shop, one stocked with plenty of foreign wares and lovingly curated by a very helpful French chap who is more than happy to let you taste before you buy and one that willingly shares French recipes that involve copious amounts of great French cheese. In the summer they have taken to offering cooked food at lunch time from a stand outside. Prices are exorbitant, but the quality is amazing, the tastes are perfect yet the portion are well on the small side.I really do like this place and will continue to be a customer. Would it be a better place with lower prices?....I don't think so, it is a swanky place with beautiful/tasty products and they demand a premium.

3CM-bCf1jnnYBy7O8XQjyA.text: 4 * - Ambience4 * - flavor and selection of cheeses4* - selection of locally  sourced goods4* - serviceHad the large cheese board and the beef charcuterie. Admittedly I just came out a 10 hour flight, eating raw beef and eating cheese wasn't quite the best thing for my lactose-intolerant tummy but even in my  jet-lagged dazed, I appreciated the the flavors and the atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. The Cheese Room
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. Cheeseboard and beef tartar
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. Cheeseboards of the day

X85UWD1LV48tmGOgjF0f7A.text: This is the kind of place I would like to run if I grow up. The cheese shop is out of this world. The staff knowledgeable, the selection fantastic. I found it by accident - when researching "Real Bread". There is a movement in London towards properly made, artisinal bread. Long, slow fermentation, natural ingredients, good shaping... La Fromagerie popped up as such a place. I went and was blown away. Walking in to the main store, you are overwhelmed by fresh smells of mint, basil, and the general goodness of fresh produce. They keep the cheese in its own room (cool and smelly). Some of the cheeses need ankle bracelets to stop them from escaping. Especially the Muenster. One of the best ever.And then you can sit and have a glass of wine and a cheese/charcuterie plate in another part of the rather sprawling space. Absolutely outstanding.

uVUFiITFpPGb4D2FIxZNWg.text: Trendy and tasty place for a snack, but ensure you try to reserve a table. It gets very busy around lunch and at the weekends.

eXxne7L419Dds8SeCcBttw.text: What a lovely place! La Fromagerie consists of a delicatessen (with a separate cheese section) and integrated shared dining area. Judging by how busy the place was on a Monday lunchtime, I'd be a bit scared to come here at the weekend. They offer a tasting menu with accompanying wine, as well as an a la carte option of yummy delicacies. We opted for an absolutely delicious tart and frittata and home made strawberry & rhubarb cordial (they probably could have been a bit more generous with the sirup quantity ). We just about managed to avoid the temptation of a cheese board, but just couldn't resist trying one of the sweet options. The Sicilian apple cake was divine and much lighter than feared.I will definitely come back when next in the area; or when planning my next dinner party, as all the produce in the shop looks delicious and quite unusual.

xK262WCATf_1uYZzUF2dYA.text: Alors là je craque! The best cheese place in London! A great cheese room, Nice deli, Nice fine food. A great wine selection. Superb place!

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom

Dqiq7tyLdiMM5ylj1mG-uA.text: Marylebone is a special place for lovers of London and La Fromagerie does the same for lovers of cheese and all that accompanies it. What if a good friend had spent a part of her life understanding all there is about cheese? Well her house would look like this, well almost. The feeling here is like a festive occasion so yes there is a busy atmosphere, lots of like minded people lost in food heaven. This is a slow food type of place so you better feel like settling in and relaxing.  With the well curated wine list and such well thought out food where else would you possibly want to be?You can follow on twitter to see the days menu and pounce when the mood is right. I enjoy a communal table, especially when traveling since your sure to met interesting people along the way. Let them set you up with wine, cheese and charcuterie  and lose yourself in food heaven!

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. French cheeses
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. cheese room & don't miss this place
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. cheese room

o5b4CH6zVetYGH6N-t-x_Q.text: this is one of those places that makes wifey and I want to move to London. The selection of cheese is amazing, and it's a shame that potential US customs issues kept us from buying half of their stock!We als had a very lovely brunch. All of the ingredients were extremely fresh and seemed as if they had been brought from some hidden farmland behind the store.

lj9p8KKjiIgX18EAa8vsmQ.text: If you like cheese, this is the best place to visit in London. And I've eaten a lot of cheese.They have a whole refrigerated room full of cheese, from local English favourites to France, of course, and beyond. If you sit down for a meal, you can't make reservations but you can enjoy delicious platters of cheese. On my most recent visit, I enjoyed the two platters available for breakfast and split them with my group.Gluten free notes: Cheese is naturally gluten free. Plenty for you to eat here.

Esg__Mc78lclEBbcq6DBFA.text: This wonderful little cheese shop/café is one of my favourite places in London. If you're as much of a cheese fan as I am (I'm a pretty big fan) then you will be in for a real treat. The cheese is out of this world and the staff are more than happy to show you the purpose-built cheese room which will make you weak at the knees! They also host special events which are equally as decadent and just fabulous! I went to a fondue evening about a year ago and had the most enjoyable evening! Great for special occasions as it is quite pricey - you'll find me here on my birthday most years!

Nq4WGbjhGxguj3GS0H_YnA.text: Excellent cheese shop. Ask for Gabriel when you get there - he's amazing, and I've never had a better conversation about cheese (trust me, I've had more than you think). They carry a couple of rare American cheeses, too!

nPI7PbEbygIDVwAP0LFk9w.text: La Fromagerie is a cheese shop and restaurant well worth visiting for tourists and locals alike.  Matt B. and I stopped in for a simple lunch of meat and cheese, and it was wonderful.The place is charming, a combination of gourmet store and restaurant with a dining area surrounded by tantalizing wares.  The restaurant portion is small and intimate, with a couple of communal tables as well as some counter seating.  Service was fine, though hardly worth noting.We split a small cheese plate and a small charcuterie plate for £8.75 and £9.75, respectively.  Neither plate was very well explained, but we did get a list of the cheeses.  Everything was delicious.The cheese plate brought five different varieties, served with figs.  The Valencay was a rich goat cheese, the Waterloo a soft cow.  The Boschenkase was a strong, aged cow's cheese, and the Crayeux de Roncq was another full-bodied cow.  My favorite was probably the Bavarian blue - I'm partial to blue cheese, and this one was lovely, with a creamy texture and nutty flavor.  The plate as a whole was successful because despite my sad inability to put the differences into words, all five cheeses were distinct and delectable.The charcuterie plate was also great, with an assortment of salami, thin shaved ham, and goose rillettes served with a celeriac remoulade, cornichons, and crusty white bread.  I've had better rillettes, I will say, but these were good, nice and fatty and easy to spread.  All the meat was quality, and Matt and I enjoyed alternating meat and cheese with bread as if we were on a picnic.The rest of the menu looked intriguing as well, but if I make it back, I may just end up repeating my order.  Meat and cheese may be straightforward, but La Fromagerie does both better than most.

GPBckVLrdm3OJznKyUyXPw.text: This review is only for breakfast as I have not shopped in the grocery store.  Service is always good and I really enjoy the atmosphere from the heavy wood furniture and wood floors while surrounded by gourmet grocery, including the most amazing selection of English and European cheeses.I have found the coffee to be hit or miss.  They serve it in a French press (or cafetiere as it is called in the UK) and twice the coffee was ground too fine leaving a copious amount of silt in the bottom of each cup.  The use of a French press requires a coarser grind.  Breakfast here is also much more expensive than at other options in the Marylebone area.That said at least once I like to come here for the cheese plate and atmosphere.

oHPF6p1blpdENmN-zF67Sw.text: I loved being in the refrigerated cheese room!The cheesemonger was extremely knowledgeable, easily recommending substitutes when I found out they didn't have the cheese I wanted. An incredible selection. I'll be back on my next trip to London.

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. inside the refrigerated cheese room

iX6KocDZtuQxirvkJJXqlA.text: This is a food lover's den. This small shop is packed with gourmet foods including incredible fresh produce that you won't find in an ordinary store. My jaw dropped just looking at all the beautiful shapes and colors of heirloom tomatos, some I've never seen before. The variety of produce and gourmet products in one small shop is impressive. The real show stopper here is the cheese room - holy cow! Packed full of all types of cheese. The selection is mind blowing. It's no wonder they were voted the best cheese shop in London. I'd love to be a mouse locked up in that room nibbling away at everything.In the back, there is a small space with tables where you can taste a small menu of freshly prepared food of the day for breakfast, lunch or an afternoon snack. They also have wine & cheese tasting plates - I will be back for a wine & cheese tasting. Oh and best part for me is they are located right next to my favorite butcher - The Ginger Pig making it the perfect Sunday shopping trip to La Fromagerie where I can be swaddled in foodie bliss and then to the Marylebone farmers market across the street, ending with a trip to the butcher for my short rib or pork shoulder order which I can't seem to find anywhere else. TGIF, I can't wait to go this weekend!

v6XMTpbHKiglS4iq54WaCg.text: A very special place, although the service can sometimes be a little tepid. But they will let you have your table for hours, nibbling away at one of their boards of perfectly-kept and lovingly-selected cheese. Wine list is extensive but the house rose is extraordinary (and how often do you get to say that?). A real home away from home when in London. Their store is also exquisite, stocked with fresh produce and delicacies like pots of French yogurt, perfect grapes, pumpkins, and candied violets.

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. La Fromagerie entrance.
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. La Fromagerie's French cheese board and rose.

4cxhrzca231PHpv7_K4t1A.text: If I said I bought the biggest clove of garlic that I have ever seen at La Fromagerie you would be none the wiser as to what this place is. This place is a combination shop and (cheese and wine) tasting / cafe area. I confess I have only used the shop and have not fully sampled the sit down  tasting/eating experience - you can look to other reviews that cover this. Though I will say there are friendly communal tables inside which seat  16, 8, 5 people and there are some tables for two.The fresh produce and the vast choice of cheese makes this place worth a visit. Everything about this place screams quality...and I would say the price mirrors this but I say worth it.In any event I bought the biggest clove of garlic you have ever seen...it lasted me absolutely ages and....okay the fact I smelled of the garlic and the cheese ruined my love life for a wee while but....I still say worth it....

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom

o8fYBQH-HHUpRaui6G8uLQ.text: Tucked away from the main road, I fell in love with this place as soon as I stepped through the door. Thanks to my amazing BF for the stop on our London tour.It's like a farmer's market meets decadent cheese shop.  Communal tables at the back and a delightful afternoon tea selection.I will be frequenting this place often.

up3Rl4_dnY6-jHTSJujbFg.text: Not too much English spoken here, but a very helpful staff and reasonably priced food! Cheese was great and they kept bringing bread and we were stuffed! It was fun to read about cheese while eating it too :) Not great for large groups.

E0tX1ihDe5C_C39AJuiTdw.text: La Fromagerie quite possibly might be my favorite shop in all of London so many gourmet choices for all things for the foody or aspiring foody.   Love love love the cheese room and their cheesemonger is an excellent resource for finding that special cheese!  Ask to try some to see what ya like.  I get excited every-time I walk into this shop.

0DUespEH8FFU1GFPIv2O3w.text: La Fromagerie is one of two cheese and wine places on the same street in the heart of Marylebone Village. It is a small and intimate place, which serves good wines, and not just the French stuff (yay!). We went there around 10p and got a nice table. The cheese plate was good but we felt it didn't have much variety. For wine, the Valpolicella was nice and went well with the cheese. Definitely worth doing this place, especially after dinner. I think they also do brunch, but I haven't tried that yet.

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom

lCkpZ30Jv5w_fXXgpZlZKA.text: My favorite breakfast of brunch spot in Marlyebone area. The feeling of sitting in the middle of a grocery store is curious and fun. It feels like you're in London. The David Mellor designs and made cutlery is a bonus.

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom

lemJtQxI7eeoJSMm15nVrw.text: Swung by for a quick lunch. They have prepackaged sandwiches when you walk in for £4.5, which is such a steal. The special for that day was eggplant, dried tomato (so good!), capretta toscana, and greens on a delicious focaccia. Picked up some apples to round out a satiating meal. It's an in and out kind of place, and I'd highly recommend it. My suggestion: buy a sandwich and drink and eat it in Regent's Park, if you're able wait during the walk!

5dCcjIu5Kwsdy-yPoUR0jA.text: Wonderful boutique with fabulous cheeses in a shoppe right out of the turn of the century. Of course, it is modern but it is fashioned after the stores of yore which makes the experience all the more pleasant. If you don't have time to shop, just open the door, take a whiff and continue on your way. Your olfactory senses will be dancing in your brain all the way to the end of the street.

xklEk5gS1xBNdM88Tf6s5Q.text: Absolutely delicious spot for brunch! They change their menu daily so it's always something different. You can browse their shop as you wait to be seated and whet your appetite with the sight of their delectable offerings. I went for the pancakes with figs, walnuts and mascarpone cheese and they were absolutely heavenly. My dining partner had a beef carpaccio which was just perfection according to him. The service was very attentive and the ambience of the place is really charming. The only reason I didn't give a 4-star review is that my food came a good 5 minutes after my partner's which I wasn't too delighted by.

YjunV8q_9jlhIJzy3EwI_w.text: This place normally rates a three with me. It's never super great but the ambience is nice to chill out in. Went there today and seriously, what is with wait staff who don't bother doing their jobs? Got to the sign that says please wait to be seated. My pregnant wife and I stood there as waiters walked past before I eventually got bored of it and asked to sit down in the half empty restaurant. After seating the waiters (maybe 6 or 7 in total) would rush to serve people (again in the half empty place) and not bother to look or pay attention when we'd try to get their attention to order. Went to providores instead which is always better... Think I'll stop entertaining even trying to give fromagerie a chance.

U_POXMFZKG-A44NJhkhHTQ.text: I came here with a colleague on my first morning in London per his suggestion and I was pleased with his recommendation. We walked in and there is a grocery store/market and then in the back is the restaurant portion. We were seated right away at a small table for 2 and given menus. Our server came over and took our drink order while we looked over the menu.I decided to go with the Farmhouse Breakfast which included 3 different cheeses, cantaloupe, yogurt, prosciutto, and bread. It was all really good and fresh. I also got English breakfast tea, since I was in London. Breakfast was fulfilling, but not heavy. After we ate, we walked around the store and went into there cheese refrigerator which is a climate controlled room filled with tons of cheeses. It was really neat and the guy working in there was very friendly and let us try a few cheeses before purchasing. This is a great local store and restaurant that I hope to visit when I'm back in London.

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. Farmhouse Breakfast
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. Menu

HiOOOKIhcQOUEGO1kUmQEQ.text: Very Nice place. And perfect for French people who want to enjoy French fresh food.Vous attendrez un petit peu car il n y a pas beaucoup de couverts. Mais cela vaut le coup! Vous aurez même la possibilité de faire vos courses avec D excellents produits.

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom. I love it

wmggw7G6LLZOetKcEURmhg.text: I really appreciate that they provide cheeses and other products difficult to find in London. But prices are crazy : 12.75/kg for Muscat grapes, 88/kg for cepes, and the list goes on.

hSNwdAyEnO0C0647ZV9KLg.text: Shakespeare wrote about this place:"This blessed clot, this earth, this realm, this cheese."Fromage is actually just part of this gourmet shop/eatery.  My review isn't based on eating here, but rather shopping here.  For cheese.Here you'll find - in a special climate controlled and glass-sealed room - a very nice variety of cheese from all over the world (though mostly Europe).  Unlike many cheese vendor experiences, where everything is down low in a glass case, everything here is on display, right in front of your nose (planned perfectly).  This allows you to browse on your own, but I've always found there to be staff on hand to answer questions and offer samples.  Just today I walked in and asked for, "runny, smelly, French for 2" and just a few minutes later I'm heading out the door with  5 quid's worth of liquid gold."To Brie or not to Brie.  That is the question."

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom
Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom

HUNRo90o-JkFDd8SFnvv8A.text: Love this place. Have been many times now and the food is always perfect. Had the most wonderful chicken broth soup. Was sublime and could subsist on it forever. Waitstaff not exceptionally warm but well worth a visit.

cOjyE1JO-B8lVPoA3NvVEA.text: Bought some cheese here and took it home. The next day it was covered in mold. I took it back and was insulted and treated very poorly. The snotty staff were very patronizing. Just replace the cheese and drop the attitude.

7T3NdPCHeeRgpHvndE7MRg.text: I am always keen on wine and cheese; you don't have to ask me twice. Therefore when my friend proposed La Fromagerie I jumped at the idea especially as the online images looked great. Unfortunately, it is just another place in London with a slick appearance and disappointing service.The staff were incredibly unpleasant and might as well have just said that they did not enjoy being there, nor did they want to speak with the customers. It would have been much more effective (and almost more appreciated) than the passive aggression and the seldom faux-smiles. Just go to Gordon's Wine Bar - better selection, and better vibe by far.

P7hrNGumlv8F4BvMjgsTdA.text: The cafe has never impressed me. But the actual cheese and ingredients you can buy here are truly special!

20JjceFT_pqhe5R96HfvSQ.text: You walk into an oxygenated cave to discover an Ali Baba's cava of cheeses from across the continent from hard to soft, goats to ewes, from pure to herb-wrapped or truffle infused...and they have an expert knowledge of cheese!

photos.caption: Photo of La Fromagerie - London, United Kingdom

qET4JOrgVaeLSRpP-BiPtA.text: This place is unusual and isn't the cheapest - however they have a great selection of high quality produce (oil, jam, cheese). I have been in a few times and found the staff slightly rude and awkward. My last trip wasn't as bad. The decor is farmers market themed and smells great - small outside sitting. The big positive is their coffee, possibly one of the best I've had.

OY6IFME5wm-nK65i5mrqgw.text: This place is really cute for a little wine and cheese happy hour. We thought the wine list was a bit pricey, but the cheese boards are very reasonable and have generous portions.

CMOFNb9BGqapoVALPhdicA.text: So this is what it's like to die and go to cheese heaven. The look and feel of La Fromagerie screams effortless cool but is surprisingly staffed by friendly, knowledgable staff who appear to love the foodstuffs as much as the patrons. First things first, breakfast at the restaurant is amazing. The concentration, unsurprisingly, is on letting the true flavors of the food sing through simple recipes. Service was excellent and the latte delicious. Now, the produce: The smoked salmon is made in-house and is so tasty; the bread is to die for; and you can pick up some amazing cheeses that shockingly won't break the bank. All in all, this is a foodies paradise but can definitely be appreciated by anyone visiting the neighborhood.
